Award.AwardTitle: RUI: Interacting effects of climate and invasive herbivores on island plant populations and communities: Santa Rosa Island as a model system
Award.AbstractNarration:
Global climate change and invasion by non-native species are considered among the most important physical and biological drivers, respectively, of future changes and extinctions in ecological communities. These drivers can interact in complex ways, yet relatively little research has been done on their combined effects in a single ecosystem. Cattle, deer, and elk were introduced to Santa Rosa Island, part of the Channel Islands National Park, more than a century ago, but were removed from the island beginning in 1998. Long-term data sets from Santa Rosa Island will be used to develop statistical and population models for five rare plant species and quantify how they have responded to both climatic variation and the removal of invasive herbivores. A parallel analysis will be used to determine effects of these factors on the composition of island plant communities. Comparing responses for both individual populations and communities will test how well predictions for a few well-studied species can be extrapolated to larger communities. The project also will assess whether species responses are correlated with their life histories, an approach which could be used to improve predictions about which species are at risk.

The results of this work will contribute to more informed conservation management, especially for the Channel Islands National Park, which supports 75 endemic plant species. The project will also enable continued collection of valuable long-term data sets that will be accessible for use by other researchers. This study will support mentorship and training of undergraduate students by creating 2-4 summer research and senior thesis opportunities each year. The data will also contribute to development of course materials for teaching quantitative skills, to be made available on the web and in educational journals. Finally, the project will involve substantial public education and outreach efforts.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Global climate change and the effects of non-native invasive species are among the most important potential causes of biodiversity loss. Physical factors like climate and biological ones like invasive species can also interact in complicated ways that are difficult to predict if they are studied separately. However, the combined effects of climate change and non-native invasions are rarely considered at the same time, especially for multiple species in an ecosystem. This project contributed to additional collection and analysis of long-term monitoring data from Santa Rosa Island (SRI) in the Channel Islands National Park. We used these data to develop statistical and population models that determined how climate and non-native pigs, cattle, deer and elk affect island plants. Oceanic islands support a much higher percentage of global biodiversity for their land area than mainland habitats. Non-native species also have disproportionately strong negative impacts on islands. This project provided important information about how well removal of non-native herbivores works as a strategy to protect island plant species.

 

First, the project determined effects of non-native herbivore removals on health of the entire island rare and endemic plant community. Approximately one-third of SRI was searched and populations of 64 species mapped. Comparison with baseline records from 1995 allowed an assessment of recovery since herbivore removal began in 1998. The data document a strong rebound in the rare plants. For example, the average number of species in five canyons increased by more than 200% and their abundance by more than 2000%. These results show that removing introduced herbivores from SRI led to a surprisingly rapid recovery of many threatened species, even though a long history of intense grazing had substantially degraded the habitat.

 

Second, we used this large data set to test approaches for optimizing collection of monitoring data when resources are limited. Researchers have hypothesized that information about species life history, such as life span and age of first reproduction, can help predict extinction risk and responses to management when other data are lacking. However, we found no evidence that either local rarity or the strength of recovery correlated with life history. Instead, carrying out at least some monitoring in most of the habitat on SRI was a much more effective strategy for accurately detecting the pattern of recovery than more intensively monitoring a smaller area. This result may aid in design of more effective and efficient ecological monitoring in other, similar plant communities.

 

Third, the project supported four years of additional data collection in long-term monitoring plots for five rare plant species. These data were used to test responses to both climatic variation and herbovire removal over the last twenty years. Results show a range of responses among species, and we have identified some of the most important factors that explain those differences.  For example,Castilleja mollis, and Jepsonia malvifolia survivorship both increased when herbivores were removed. However, while J. malivofolia populations have shown a strong recovery, C. mollis still continues to decline. Our analyses confirmed that negative effects of increased temperatures on C. mollis are the likely explanation. This important interaction means that the benefits of non-native herbivore removal were masked by the negative effects of climate, and vice versa, in a way that would not have been detected without analyses that included both.
